statement.text: Deep venous reconstruction encompasses surgical procedures to restore venous outflow or valve function, including venous bypass (Palma procedure), valve repair, valve transplant, and endovascular recanalization/stenting for chronic obstruction.

explanation.intuition: When the major deep veins are blocked or their valves don't work, surgery can either bypass the blockage, fix the valves, or transplant working valves from elsewhere - essentially plumbing repairs to restore proper drainage.
explanation.key_insight: Deep venous reconstruction is reserved for patients with severe post-thrombotic syndrome or chronic obstruction not responding to compression. Patient selection is critical - these are complex procedures with variable results.
explanation.technical_details: Procedures: (1) Palma procedure: GSV crossover bypass for unilateral iliac occlusion, (2) Valve repair: external valvuloplasty, internal valvuloplasty, (3) Valve transplant: axillary valve segment to femoral vein, (4) Neovalve: autogenous tissue reconstruction, (5) Endovascular: IVUS-guided iliofemoral stenting. Patient selection: severe PTS (Villalta >15), failed conservative therapy, confirmed obstruction on imaging.

procedural_details.palma_procedure: Contralateral GSV tunneled suprapubically to bypass unilateral iliofemoral occlusion
procedural_details.valve_transplant: Axillary valve-containing segment to femoral vein
procedural_details.endovascular: IVUS-guided iliofemoral stenting for chronic obstruction

primary_sources.title: Journal of Vascular Surgery: Venous and Lymphatic Disorders

clinical_pearls: Palma procedure uses contralateral GSV to bypass unilateral iliac occlusion
Patient selection is critical - reserve for severe PTS failing conservative therapy
IVUS-guided stenting increasingly used for iliofemoral obstruction
